div.p: Greetings. I received the wine through your relative Theodor and I give your kindness the greatest thanks for this, which I will repay if I live. I am very surprised why I receive nothing from you, which I am eagerly expecting.

I am now in mourning and not slight sorrow: after the death of Gwalther's wife, soon my beloved Elisabeth fell ill and on the third day she happily entrusted her spirit to God; she was the wife of Mr. Simler.
Now my daughter Anna, the wife of Zwingli, is also at death's door, in whose house I am writing this. What God has decided about me and my other family members, He knows; I am prepared.

If I depart from here, I ask you to ensure that my children receive the money from SÃ¼leri, which is owed, etc. Farewell forever, most esteemed brother in Christ; my grief does not allow me to write more now.
Because I am human, I console myself in the meantime with the promises of Christ, and that my daughters expire in the sincere confession and invocation of Christ.
Pray to the Lord for us. November 23, 1565.
Lavater and Zwingli, who are attending the dying, greet you. Greet Mr. Consul and friends.
To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church in Chur, my esteemed lord and dearest brother. Chur.
